title: How to Replace an Outdoor Water Faucet

methods.name: Installing a Faucet on an Exposed Outdoor Pipe

steps.headline: Shut off the water supply to your home.
steps.description: The main water supply for your home is either inside or outside your home depending on where you live and the climate. If you have a basement or live in a cold climate, check near your water heater where the pipes enter your home. If you don’t have a basement or live in a warm climate, the valve may be connected to a pipe by your faucet outside. Rotate the valve so it’s perpendicular to the pipe to prevent water from entering it. If you pipe has a circular valve, rotate it clockwise until it doesn’t go any further to turn off the water. You will not be able to use water in the rest of your home while the supply is turned off.Tip: If you still can’t locate the valve that controls your water supply, you may need to turn off the supply from an underground utility box outside your home. Look around your yard for a black or gray plastic cover that’s level with the ground and lift it up to expose the valve. Find the rectangular metal valve and rotate it until it’s perpendicular to the pipe.

steps.headline: Turn on the outdoor faucet to drain the pipes.
steps.description: Rotate the valve on your faucet to open it so the water can drain out. Keep the valve open until no more water comes out, which means the pipes leading to the faucets are empty and you can continue with your repairs. If you turned off the water supply from a valve in your basement and the faucet continues to run at full power, then the faucet may be connected to the supply before it enters your home. Turn off the water supply in the underground utility box, which is usually located somewhere in your yard.

steps.headline: Hold the pipe connected to the faucet in place with a pipe wrench.
steps.description: The pipe could break or weaken if it’s accidentally bent or rotated while you replace the faucet. Open the jaws of a pipe wrench so they can fit around the exposed pipe connected to the end of your faucet. Tighten the wrench around the pipe and hold the wrench in place with your nondominant hand. Keep holding the pipe in place throughout the process of removing the faucet. You can get a pipe wrench from your local hardware store if you don’t already have one.

steps.headline: Rotate the faucet counterclockwise with pliers to remove it.
steps.description: Grab the outside of the faucet with a pair of pliers so you have a firm grip. Hold the pipe the faucet’s connected to firmly in place as you spin the faucet counterclockwise to loosen it. Continue spinning the old faucet until you’re able to remove it by hand. If the faucet doesn’t unscrew easily, try spraying a lubricant, such as WD-40, on the connection to loosen it more.

steps.headline: Get a new faucet that matches the size and fitting of the pipe.
steps.description: Most faucets come in diameters that are either ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) or ⁄4 inch (1.9 cm). Check the dimensions of the pipe that your old faucet was connected to and make sure the new faucet will fit. Look at the old faucet to check if it has a male end with exposed threading or a female end with a port that the pipe screws into. You can buy new outdoor faucets from your local hardware or home improvement store.

steps.headline: Wrap the threading onto the new faucet 3–4 times with Teflon tape.
steps.description: Teflon tape prevents any water from leaking out of the pipe connection. Start the end of the Teflon tape anywhere on the threading that connects the faucet to the pipe. Roll the tape clockwise around the threading 3–4 times so the threads are completely covered by it. Rip off the strip of tape and press the end firmly against the threads to make sure it’s secure. You can buy Teflon tape from your local hardware store. Don’t wrap the Teflon tape counterclockwise or else it may come undone when you screw the faucet back onto the pipe. If the exposed threading is on the pipe rather than on the faucet, wrap the Teflon tape around the pipe’s end instead.

steps.headline: Tighten the faucet onto the pipe with a wrench so it points down.
steps.description: Grip the main pipe with the pipe wrench again so it doesn’t twist or move around while you’re working. Put the threading into the port on the pipe and start turning it clockwise to secure it. Once it’s hand-tight, grip the faucet with a pair of pliers and continue tightening until you feel resistance. When you finish, make sure the faucet points down, or else it won’t work or drain properly. Be careful not to overtighten the faucet since it could cause the pipe to break or leak when you run water.

steps.headline: Turn on your water supply to test the new faucet.
steps.description: Go back to your main water supply and open the valve again so water can go through your pipes. Once the water’s on, turn the valve on your faucet on so water starts flowing through it. If the water comes through the faucet without leaks, then it’s working and ready to use. If the faucet is leaking where it connects to the pipe, turn off the water supply again and try tightening the faucet more. If it still doesn’t work, then remove the faucet and check the tape on around the threading to make sure it hasn’t come undone.

steps.headline: Turn off the main water supply for your home.
steps.description: Locate the main water supply, which is usually near where the pipes enter your home from outside. Rotate the valve until it’s perpendicular to the pipe so the water stops running through your home. If you don’t see a supply valve in your basement, look in your yard for a black or gray plastic cover that’s level with the ground. Remove the cover and locate the rectangular valve that controls your water. Turn the valve so it’s perpendicular to the pipe. If the main water supply has a circular valve, then rotate it clockwise to turn off the water. If you still can’t find your water supply valve, contact your utility company to turn off the water in your home for you. Some outdoor faucets have a valve on the pipe leading to them so you can close their water supply without turning it off in the rest of your home. If the outdoor faucet doesn’t have a separate valve, then you won’t be able to use the water in the rest of your home while you’re working.

steps.headline: Open the outdoor faucet to drain the water out.
steps.description: Rotate the valve on your faucet until it’s open and water flows out of it freely. Keep the valve open until all of the water drains out so you don’t have to worry about anything leaking during your repairs. Once the water stops, you can leave the valve open or close it again. Don’t try to remove a faucet without draining the pipe first since the water may be stored at high pressure inside and come shooting out from the pipe. If the water doesn’t get less pressurized coming out of the faucet, then you may need to turn off the water supply valve in an underground utility box located somewhere in your yard.

steps.headline: Unscrew the screws holding the base of the faucet against the wall.
steps.description: Most frost-free faucets have bases that connect to the outside of your home to secure them in place. Use a screwdriver or a drill to turn the screws counterclockwise and remove them. Set the screws aside so you can use them later when you put in your new faucet. Your faucet may not have screws depending on the model. If it doesn’t have screws, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Locate where the faucet connects to your pipes inside your home.
steps.description: Go inside your home so you’re on the opposite side of the wall with your faucet, and look for a pipe leading in from outside. If there’s a wall in front of the pipe and you can’t see it, you will have to use a utility knife or drywall saw to cut through the wall. The end of the faucet inside your home will look like a long silver tube that screws directly into another pipe that leads to the main water supply line. If you aren’t able to access your pipes from inside your home, then you need to contact a plumber or a specialist to locate the pipes for you.

steps.headline: Unscrew the faucet from the pipes inside your home to prevent damage.
steps.description: Grip the faucet tube with a pair of pliers and the pipe it connects to with a pipe wrench. Hold the pipe wrench securely in place so the pipe doesn’t twist around, and rotate the faucet counterclockwise to loosen it. Once it’s completely loose, it will separate easily from the pipe. The pipe your faucet connects to may have a wingnut so you can easily unscrew it by hand without causing any damage.Warning: Don’t try to unscrew a frost-free faucet from outside since you could break or bend the pipe it connects to inside your home and cause a leak.

steps.headline: Pull the faucet out from the wall from outside.
steps.description: Go back outside once you’ve detached the faucet from the pipe. Grab the faucet and pull it straight out from the wall to pull it out from the hole in the side of your home. The tube will easily come straight from the wall when you’re finished.

steps.headline: Get a new frost-free faucet that matches the diameter of your pipes.
steps.description: Frost-free faucets have a long stem so water doesn’t freeze inside the end of your faucet and back up your pipes. Get a new frost-free faucet that matches the length of the old one so you can easily reinstall it on the pipe. Make sure the faucet diameter is the same as your pipe, which is usually ⁄2–⁄4 inch (1.3–1.9 cm) wide. You can get a frost-free faucet from a hardware or home improvement store. Don’t replace a frost-free faucet with a regular faucet since they’re more likely to freeze during cold weather.

steps.headline: Wrap the end of the faucet with 3–4 layers of Teflon tape.
steps.description: Teflon tape waterproofs the connection to prevent leaks inside your home. Start the end of the Teflon tape along the faucet’s threading where it connects to the pipe. Roll the tape clockwise around the threads until you have 3-4 layers. Rip the strip of tape off from the roll and press the end firmly against the threads to secure it. Don’t roll the Teflon tape counterclockwise since it will easily tear off when you try to screw the faucet into the pipe.

steps.headline: Screw the end of pipe onto the threading of the faucet.
steps.description: Slide the faucet through the hole on the outside of your home and push it in as far as it can go. Then go inside your home so you can see where the end of the faucet tube lines up with the pipe. Hold the pipe securely in place with your wrench and rotate the faucet tube by hand to screw it back in. Continue tightening the faucet until you feel resistance. Check outside to make sure the faucet points down, and make any adjustments by unscrewing the faucet slightly from the pipe. Be careful not to overtighten the faucet since you could cause the pipe to break or crack.

steps.headline: Turn on the water supply to check for any leaks.
steps.description: Once you have the faucet firmly attached, turn the main supply valve so it’s parallel to the pipe to turn your water back on. Check the faucet connection to make sure it’s not leaking or dripping. If it’s not, then you  can move on. If the faucet connection is leaking, turn off the water again and check that the Teflon tape is still intact or that the faucet is tight enough on the pipe.

steps.headline: Secure the base of the faucet to the outside of your home with screws.
steps.description: Go back outside and locate the screw holes in the faucet base. Put the screws from the old base into the holes and use your drill to secure them to the side of your home. Continue tightening them until the faucet doesn’t move around outside anymore.

text: Installing a Faucet on an Exposed Outdoor Pipe Shut off the water supply to your home. The main water supply for your home is either inside or outside your home depending on where you live and the climate. If you have a basement or live in a cold climate, check near your water heater where the pipes enter your home. If you don’t have a basement or live in a warm climate, the valve may be connected to a pipe by your faucet outside. Rotate the valve so it’s perpendicular to the pipe to prevent water from entering it. If you pipe has a circular valve, rotate it clockwise until it doesn’t go any further to turn off the water. You will not be able to use water in the rest of your home while the supply is turned off.Tip: If you still can’t locate the valve that controls your water supply, you may need to turn off the supply from an underground utility box outside your home. Look around your yard for a black or gray plastic cover that’s level with the ground and lift it up to expose the valve. Find the rectangular metal valve and rotate it until it’s perpendicular to the pipe. Turn on the outdoor faucet to drain the pipes. Rotate the valve on your faucet to open it so the water can drain out. Keep the valve open until no more water comes out, which means the pipes leading to the faucets are empty and you can continue with your repairs. If you turned off the water supply from a valve in your basement and the faucet continues to run at full power, then the faucet may be connected to the supply before it enters your home. Turn off the water supply in the underground utility box, which is usually located somewhere in your yard. Hold the pipe connected to the faucet in place with a pipe wrench. The pipe could break or weaken if it’s accidentally bent or rotated while you replace the faucet. Open the jaws of a pipe wrench so they can fit around the exposed pipe connected to the end of your faucet. Tighten the wrench around the pipe and hold the wrench in place with your nondominant hand. Keep holding the pipe in place throughout the process of removing the faucet. You can get a pipe wrench from your local hardware store if you don’t already have one. Rotate the faucet counterclockwise with pliers to remove it. Grab the outside of the faucet with a pair of pliers so you have a firm grip. Hold the pipe the faucet’s connected to firmly in place as you spin the faucet counterclockwise to loosen it. Continue spinning the old faucet until you’re able to remove it by hand. If the faucet doesn’t unscrew easily, try spraying a lubricant, such as WD-40, on the connection to loosen it more. Get a new faucet that matches the size and fitting of the pipe. Most faucets come in diameters that are either ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) or ⁄4 inch (1.9 cm). Check the dimensions of the pipe that your old faucet was connected to and make sure the new faucet will fit. Look at the old faucet to check if it has a male end with exposed threading or a female end with a port that the pipe screws into. You can buy new outdoor faucets from your local hardware or home improvement store. Wrap the threading onto the new faucet 3–4 times with Teflon tape. Teflon tape prevents any water from leaking out of the pipe connection. Start the end of the Teflon tape anywhere on the threading that connects the faucet to the pipe. Roll the tape clockwise around the threading 3–4 times so the threads are completely covered by it. Rip off the strip of tape and press the end firmly against the threads to make sure it’s secure. You can buy Teflon tape from your local hardware store. Don’t wrap the Teflon tape counterclockwise or else it may come undone when you screw the faucet back onto the pipe. If the exposed threading is on the pipe rather than on the faucet, wrap the Teflon tape around the pipe’s end instead. Tighten the faucet onto the pipe with a wrench so it points down. Grip the main pipe with the pipe wrench again so it doesn’t twist or move around while you’re working. Put the threading into the port on the pipe and start turning it clockwise to secure it. Once it’s hand-tight, grip the faucet with a pair of pliers and continue tightening until you feel resistance. When you finish, make sure the faucet points down, or else it won’t work or drain properly. Be careful not to overtighten the faucet since it could cause the pipe to break or leak when you run water. Turn on your water supply to test the new faucet. Go back to your main water supply and open the valve again so water can go through your pipes. Once the water’s on, turn the valve on your faucet on so water starts flowing through it. If the water comes through the faucet without leaks, then it’s working and ready to use. If the faucet is leaking where it connects to the pipe, turn off the water supply again and try tightening the faucet more. If it still doesn’t work, then remove the faucet and check the tape on around the threading to make sure it hasn’t come undone. If you have a basement or live in a cold climate, check near your water heater where the pipes enter your home.

You will not be able to use water in the rest of your home while the supply is turned off.Tip: If you still can’t locate the valve that controls your water supply, you may need to turn off the supply from an underground utility box outside your home.

Frost-free faucets have a long stem so water doesn’t freeze inside the end of your faucet and back up your pipes.
Get a new frost-free faucet that matches the length of the old one so you can easily reinstall it on the pipe.
Make sure the faucet diameter is the same as your pipe, which is usually ⁄2–⁄4 inch (1.3–1.9 cm) wide.
You can get a frost-free faucet from a hardware or home improvement store.
Don’t replace a frost-free faucet with a regular faucet since they’re more likely to freeze during cold weather.
Wrap the end of the faucet with 3–4 layers of Teflon tape.
Teflon tape waterproofs the connection to prevent leaks inside your home.
Start the end of the Teflon tape along the faucet’s threading where it connects to the pipe.
Roll the tape clockwise around the threads until you have 3-4 layers.
Rip the strip of tape off from the roll and press the end firmly against the threads to secure it.
Don’t roll the Teflon tape counterclockwise since it will easily tear off when you try to screw the faucet into the pipe.
Screw the end of pipe onto the threading of the faucet.
Slide the faucet through the hole on the outside of your home and push it in as far as it can go.
Then go inside your home so you can see where the end of the faucet tube lines up with the pipe.
Hold the pipe securely in place with your wrench and rotate the faucet tube by hand to screw it back in.
Continue tightening the faucet until you feel resistance.
Check outside to make sure the faucet points down, and make any adjustments by unscrewing the faucet slightly from the pipe.
Be careful not to overtighten the faucet since you could cause the pipe to break or crack.
Turn on the water supply to check for any leaks.
Once you have the faucet firmly attached, turn the main supply valve so it’s parallel to the pipe to turn your water back on.
Check the faucet connection to make sure it’s not leaking or dripping.
If it’s not, then you  can move on.
If the faucet connection is leaking, turn off the water again and check that the Teflon tape is still intact or that the faucet is tight enough on the pipe.
Secure the base of the faucet to the outside of your home with screws.
Go back outside and locate the screw holes in the faucet base.
Put the screws from the old base into the holes and use your drill to secure them to the side of your home.
Continue tightening them until the faucet doesn’t move around outside anymore.
